claim: Flublok contains 3x the hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content of standard-dose flu vaccines, which has been linked to greater immunogenicity vs standard-dose flu vaccines.
explanation: A multipanel figure of hemagglutination inhibition (HI) titers (log2 scale) at Day 0 and 1 month post-vaccination for four influenza strains (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata), in two age cohorts (18–44 and 45–64 years) and for egg-grown vs cell-grown virus assays. Within each panel, colored symbols and error bars represent different prime-boost vaccine regimens, including recombinant influenza vaccine (RIV4), standard inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV4), and cell-culture influenza vaccine (ccIIV4), with p-values comparing HI titers between groups. Evidence: At 1 month post-vaccination, RIV4 (recombinant vaccine) groups consistently show higher HI titers than IIV4 groups for multiple strains (e.g., A(H3N2) cell virus p<0.0001; B/Yamagata cell virus p<0.0001). The figure demonstrates greater immunogenicity (higher HI titers) for the recombinant vaccine (Flublok) compared to standard-dose vaccines, but it does not provide any data on the antigen dose (3× HA content). Therefore, it does not support the claim that Flublok contains 3× the HA antigen content, although it does show greater immunogenicity. Note: The figure clearly shows immunogenicity differences, but antigen content per dose is not indicated; interpretation assumes RIV4 corresponds to Flublok.

Therefore, it does not support the claim that Flublok contains 3× the HA antigen content, although it does show greater immunogenicity.
